tickets.summary: Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length
tickets.description:
As the title suggests, there seems to be vignetting showing up on Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II photos taken at 12.5 mm. Here are some sample photos to test on:

https://www.imaging-resource.com/PRODS/canon-g1x-ii/YIMG_0023.CR2.HTM
https://www.imaging-resource.com/PRODS/canon-g1x-ii/YIMG_0026.CR2.HTM

more:
https://www.imaging-resource.com/PRODS/canon-g1x-ii/canon-g1x-iiGALLERY.HTM

I checked a couple others (31mm & 63mm) and those seemed to be okay.

This lens profile is in data/db/compact-canon.xml at around line 2531.

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: This is not uncommon at the wide end of fixed zooms. The in-camera processing simply crops it away as part of correction (and this particular camera apparently *always* crops a little anyway, in order to maintain same angle of view at different aspect ratios). There actually exists a "crop" parameter as part of LensFun's [calibraton data format](http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/manual/v0.3.2/elem_calibration.html), but I don't know if any software actually does anything with it. At least, darktable doesn't seem to,  and generally likes to offer the user all available pixels as a rule. If RawTherapee uses it, it might be worth adding to the profile, I suppose?
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: I don’t really understand what we are talking about here. Frankly, I don’t see any vignetting on those shots. :-/ They are not really suitable to estimate vignetting anyway. @junkyardsparke: The cropping of the camera should not affect Lensfun’s corrections, as long as the crop factor is correctly assumed.  If it is off by the same amount that at the calibration, it should not affect either.
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text:
The problem isn't that the in-camera cropping affects the lensfun corrections, it's that Lensfun/darktable doesn't do the additional cropping that the camera does in order to hide the edges of the image circle in the corners. You can see this best on the second linked image (YIMG_0026.CR2)... with default correction in darktable there are still visible traces of the physical edge of the image circle, most easily noticed in the lower left.

You can, of course, adjust this for each image in darktable with the "scale" slider in the lens correction module, or just by using normal cropping, but there doesn't seem to be a way to "hint" within the profile itself that extra scaling is needed to emulate camera processing in this way (and darktable seems philosophically opposed to this kind of thing anyway).

So, while it's nice that the user has the option of how to make use of the full capture  area (perhaps with a more square-like crop to make use of additional vertical area), there will probably be some who will wish for an easy way to "just do what the camera does" in this regard.
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
Ah! My bad … the RAW image viewer I used apparently showed the embedded JPEG.

There is the ``<crop>`` element: http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/manual/v0.3.2/elem_calibration.html But it has never been used in the DB, and I don’t know whether the code uses it. But it is exactly for this purpose.

We could make use of it in the “autoscale” function.  This would be used by Darktable, too, without them needing to change the code.
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: As a side node, ``calibrate.py`` has the – I think undocumented – feature of having a sidecar file for each vignetting RAW which contains the line ``maximal_radius: 0.7``.  “0.7” means 70% of the image diagonal are usable.  Then, farther points are not considered for the vignetting measurement, and the resulting polynomial is much better (in the useful area). Of course, it is bad that it is not documented, and that it does not create a ``<crop>`` element.
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: Any objection to closing this?
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: That's interesting, I've seen several cases similar to this one where `maximal_radius` would be useful. I did try the `<crop>` element, but it didn't seem to have any effect in darktable, at least. Implementing it as you describe sounds good to me, but I guess should be discussed somewhere. It might be best if there was still a way to get the current "all-the-pixels" behavior if it's desired.
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: Not from me, unless it's worth keeping open a little longer as a reminder to actually add the crop tags to the profiles that need them... otherwise, I could add FIXME comments to the profiles, for the ones I can remember having this "feature"...
posts.subject: #108 Vignetting with Canon PowerShot G1X Mark II at 12.5mm focal length

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: Or, you collect the upload ID where you observed this in a GitHub issue.

tickets.summary: Laowa 7.5mm f/2.0 vignetting data
tickets.description:
I have deteermined the attached vignetting data for the Venus Laowa 7.5mm f/2.0 MFT lens (distortion and chromatic aberation are already in the database).  These data were prepared using Andreas Schneider's lens_calibate.py script (after exchanges with Andreas over bugs in script related to colorspaces, which are now sorted) using overcast sky (its UK!) and diffuser.  The data have been tested on a range of shots (particularly blue skies) and seen to be good,  i.e. no over obvious over-correction.  Focus distance changes are quite small, but anyway the data are there.  Tests indicate that the diffuser was behaving ideally and not introducing any vignetting itself, i.e transmission through diffuser was fairly constant across the sensor.

Jim

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text:
Thanks for providing the profile. It looks like this profile does very slightly over-correct on the test images that were submitted by another user (and which I used for the vignetting data recently added to the database). Could you please test the attached profile with that data, and see if it seems like the results are ok with your real-world images? I would prefer to err on the side of under-correction for the shipped version, in the event that there seems to be copy variation.

That said, your profile did provide the helpful information that this lens doesn't seem to change vignetting significantly with focus distance (probably because of being a unit-focusing lens); the other user didn't provide samples at multiple distances. Thanks again.
posts.subject: #112 Laowa 7.5mm f/2.0 vignetting data

Hi,

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text:
Focus distance is very much a factor for the modern internal-focus lenses I've used (all Micro 4/3, so compactness of design could play a part, I suppose). I wouldn't expect it to be a *major* factor until the distances were smaller than the ones in those pictures, but I think it probably depends on the specific lens in question, and might be hard to make general predictions about (strangest case I've seen so far is [this one](https://github.com/lensfun/lensfun/issues/466)).

For this reason, I feel somewhat differently than Torsten Bronger about the wisdom of only profiling lenses at infinity. For unit-focusing lenses this is probably good enough, but for lenses with moving elements I think it's a bad idea, because over-correction at closer distances seems likely, and it looks much worse than under-correction. The concern is that making the profiling too complicated will prevent people from doing it, but I think people willing to do it at all are probably looking for good results, so... I don't know what the best compromise is.

I would say that if you only want to profile at one focus distance, then it should be the distance that produces *the least vignetting*, so that it errs on the side of under- rather than over-correction for the rest of the range. Indeed, much in-camera correction seems like it may use this approach, as most images only have partial correction... this may also be an esthetic choice; absolute correction isn't always what people want to see, unless they're stitching panoramas. Of course, determining this distance might end up not being less work that just taking calibration shots at multiple distances... but given that there are still many cameras around that don't produce reliable distance info in EXIF, this may still be the best general, all-around approach.
posts.subject: #113 Sony E PZ 16-50mm F3.5-5.6 OSS vignetting

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: This doesn't surprise me. The images used for calibration should always look well-corrected - the correction model itself does a really good job with normal, radial light fall-off (it doesn't correct *color* vignetting, though, so that may be apparent even in the calibration images). The problem is that it's hard to produce really good, evenly illuminated calibration images. The diffuser-directly-on-lens method is easy, but my experience is that, for wider lenses, it actually fails for some reason (by increasing apparent vignetting and producing over-correction on real-world images). There's some discussion about that [here](https://sourceforge.net/p/lensfun/mailman/message/35538673/).
posts.subject: #113 Sony E PZ 16-50mm F3.5-5.6 OSS vignetting

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
I did those calibrations myself back in 2012 because I own those lenses.  I had a look at my old images – the correction in Darktable is perfect.  Thus, there are three possible explanations:

- My method with the diffuser plate was suboptimal
- In-camera vignetting correction is on, resulting in double correction
- There is some lens model variance, i.e. lens samples differ from each other slightly

The second point can be excluded easily: Just assure that in-camera vignetting correction is off.  At least in many Sony models, it is also applied to RAWs!
posts.subject: #113 Sony E PZ 16-50mm F3.5-5.6 OSS vignetting

tickets.summary: Tests not compiling if OpenMP not found
tickets.description:
This is about problems in the `tests/CMakeLists.txt` file.

First, the following two lines appear twice:
```
find_package(OpenMP)
set(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} ${OpenMP_CXX_FLAGS}")
```

Second, if OpenMP is not found, then `${OpenMP_CXX_FLAGS}` will be the string "NOTFOUND" which leads to compile errors. If OpenMP is strictly required for the tests, then `REQUIRED` should be added to the `find_package` call. If it's not required, then the `CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS` should be changed conditionally based on the `OpenMP_CXX_FOUND` flag.

posts.author: seebk
posts.text: Thanks, should be fixed in master now.
posts.subject: #118 Tests not compiling if OpenMP not found

posts.author: seebk
posts.text:
- **status**: open --> fixed
- **assigned_to**: seebk
posts.subject: #118 Tests not compiling if OpenMP not found

for RX10 lens: <model>DSC-RX10 & compatibles</model>

posts.author: m-a

posts.subject: #91 Fixed lenses RX10 and RX100M2 not autocorrected

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: The name of the lens model of compact cameras should not matter.  After all, many compact camera models may use the very same lens profile.  For examples, RX100 III–V all use the “DSC-RX100 III & compatibles” model.  Compact camera mounts can be identified by the fact that the mount starts with a lowercase letter.  Darktable makes use of this here: https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/blob/master/src/iop/lens.c#L1159
posts.subject: #91 Fixed lenses RX10 and RX100M2 not autocorrected

tickets.summary: lensfun "acm" model
tickets.description:
I was trying to use the lensfun-convert-lcp script. It works fine on the .lcp files given and generate a _lcps.xml as expected.

Now the database version is set to 2 and the model is set to "acm" in _lcps.xml. It seems that my lensfun version 0.3.2 does not understand this format. I have seen that a branch named acm has been merged into lensfun... So I'm confused.

Can you clarify the situation here? Where is the acm support? How to get it?

Thanks in advance,

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: ACM is in master but not released.  Probably it will be part of an upcoming 0.4 release but never be part of an 0.3.x release.  We had to change the DB format for ACM because we had to add the new ACM model.  Therefore, the version number was bumped up.

tickets.summary: Incorrect cropfactors for several Sony SLR cameras
tickets.description:
I was researching the crop factor for my new Sony A68 and saw some incorrect entries in the database regarding crop factors for (at least) the following cameras.

Sony Alpha A200
Sensor size (according to manual) 23.6×15.8 mm --> crop factor 1.523
Camera database says <cropfactor>1.534</cropfactor>

Sony Alpha A77
Sensor size (accoring to manual) 23.5 mm×15.6 mm --> crop factor 1.534
Camera database says <cropfactor>1.523</cropfactor>

I also checked Alpha 100 and Alpha A77 II, these are correct it seems.

As this is only a difference of less than 1% I guess this does not make much of a difference, but a difference it is ;)

tickets.summary: [PATCH] fix test_database running without installed lensfun
tickets.description:
Currently, `test_database` tries to load the system database, which of course is not available when building lensfun anew (e.g. in a clean build chroot).

As a solution, make tests aware of their source directory, and then change `test_database` to load the database from the in-source copy.

posts.text: I'm sorry but it is exetremly confusing which is the right way to submit patches to the lensfun project. Using this bugtracker or via github?
posts.subject: #109 Add support for Sony A7 III

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: Anything related to the Lensfun library code should be submitted here. Most of the work related to the actual lens profile database has been happening on github for a while now; these are two different kinds of work, and the github repository was set up to focus on the lens profiling work, with the calibration image uploads from Torsten's site generating issues there. I'm trying to keep most of my own activity there, but also trying to catch any database-related issues here. Hope that makes sense.

tickets.summary: ufraw segfault with nef files
tickets.description:
ufraw exits with segmentation fault

this is the dmesg error message:
ufraw[21504]: segfault at 2 ip 0000003d61e13cf5 sp 00007ffd253e4830 error 4 in liblensfun.so.0.3.1[3d61e00000+1a000]

I attach the photo hoping that it can help

the sistem is mint 17.2 64

posts.author: nlann
posts.text:
Hi,

I can correct the distortion of your image in Darktable, which also uses Lensfun. So it looks more like a UFRaw problem ?

Regards,
Nicolas
